utterances: Well, you know, it's very hard, I think, for people to think of the beginning of a process as a real concrete result, because, of course, it isn't, and it's going to take some time until you get one.
But I mean, for those of us who are close to the process, a decision to move ahead and negotiate something more concrete is at least a step in the right direction.
But you might argue that that's what you said in 1999--you personally.
That's what happened in 1992 when we started going through this whole thing.

Well, it's true, and the result of that was Kyoto, which, for all of its flaws and despite the fact that some countries may not meet the target, has actually resulted in quite a bit of activity, some of which is positive.
The EU trading system is really positive.
The fact that some countries are seriously reducing emissions is very positive.
I don't think it would have happened without the Kyoto Protocol.
But we still do have all those--a lot of countries, like Canada's, I think, emissions were up by 25 percent.
Yes.
I mean, Canada, which did sign on, has been moving in the wrong direction.
The US, which didn't sign on, has been moving in the wrong direction.
China and India, which are expected to grow, have been growing at pretty rapid rates.
So yes, we're not a lot closer to actually solving the problem.
Are they at least sympathetic about the problems, these big countries that...
Yes.

I mean, I think they are, but one thing I can say for those who signed on to the Kyoto targets, I think most of the countries did not understand that it was actually quite difficult and that it really takes a lot of time to turn these ships around.
I mean, you've got things under development.
You've got increasing demand.
In some cases, you have population growth.
Can you make these changes?
Yes.
But can you make them instantly?
I think the answer is no, which suggests that you need slightly longer time frames and a much more robust set of milestones along the way.
All right.
Thank you very much for taking time to talk to us.
My pleasure.
Eileen Claussen is the president of the Pew Center on Global Climate Change.
She was talking with us from Washington.
We're going to take a break, and when we come back, we're going to take a virtual trip at least out to Saturn, talk about some really interesting new discoveries about the moons of Saturn.
We usually talk about the moons of Jupiter a lot, but Saturn's moons are looking to be quite interesting themselves.
So stay with us.
We'll be right back.
I'm Ira Flatow, and this is TALK OF THE NATION/SCIENCE FRIDAY from NPR News.
Iowa's biggest city is confronting the farms that surround it over water pollution.
The Des Moines Water Works has announced it will sue three neighboring counties, claiming the counties are letting fertilizer runoff contaminate the drinking water in Des Moines.
It is a novel attempt to control water pollution from farms, something that has been largely unregulated.
NPR's Dan Charles reports.
The city of Des Moines gets its water from two rivers - the Raccoon River and the Des Moines - and those rivers have a problem.
Bill Stowe, general manager of the Des Moines Water Works, told Iowa Public Radio that the water often violates legal limits for a pollutant called nitrate.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We're still seeing the public water supply in central Iowa directly risked by high nitrate concentrations.
Too much nitrate can be a health risk, especially for infants just a few months old, and it costs a lot of money to remove.
Filtering out nitrate cost the Des Moines Water Works almost a million dollars in 2013.
And Stowe says we know where a lot of this nitrate is coming from.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We've been in northern Iowa with our lab personnel testing water.
The problem comes from farms, he says.
Farmers spread nitrogen fertilizer on their cornfields, it turns into nitrate and then it often runs into streams through networks of underground tile pipes that drain the soil.
Those drainage systems are managed in some cases by county governments.
When they build these artificial drainage districts that take water quickly into the Raccoon River - polluted water - they have a responsibility to us and others as downstream users.
Stowe's agency announced last week it intends to sue three upstream counties that manage those drainage systems.
We need to get now down to specific improvements that they're willing to make.
If they're not willing to make that, we'll see them in federal court.
Fertilizer runoff affects a lot more than just drinking water.
It's been killing off webs of aquatic life from small Midwestern lakes to the Gulf of Mexico.
And lots of programs have been set up to try to solve the problem.
Scientists have created tools to help farmers minimize their use of fertilizer.
John Downing, an ecologist at Iowa State University, says farmers can also build sediment-trapping ponds or create wetlands to capture water from those drainage systems.
That can be costly, though.
You'd have to take land out of production.
And if you look at the prices of land in agricultural production areas, it's very pricy.
We've got over a two-year waiting list of people wanting to put practices in place.
They don't want the establishment anymore.
They want some fresh faces who are trying to stop the reckless spending and the growth of government.

What I've tried to do is just to go out and find some of those candidates and see if I can help put a spotlight on these Republicans who, in my mind, can help us avoid a third party by giving Republicans and independents good choices in Republican primaries.
And so far, it's working.
There's only one state, Nevada, where a Tea Party group is running a third-party candidate for Senate.
Republicans do worry he could split the conservative vote in Nevada and help the embattled Democrat there, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, hang onto his job.
But on the whole, the GOP is doing a good job keeping the Tea Parties, and all their explosive political energy, inside the Republican tent.
Mara Liasson, NPR News, Washington.
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
And I'm Renee Montagne.

The book is now in the stores, but Sarah Palin's ""Going Rogue"" made the bestseller list even before it was released, even before she kicked off her high profile book tour with an interview on ""Oprah."" All of which has people wondering how Palin will use her celebrity.
Here's NPR's national political correspondent, Mara Liasson.
Never before has a former vice presidential candidate, and a losing one at that, generated this kind of attention.
The media just can't get enough of Sarah Palin.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOWS)
Sarah Palin rolls out her new book.
Now the latest on Sarah Palin.
New questions about Palin's future.
Please welcome Sarah Palin.
Palin is still controversial, charismatic, polarizing and fascinating.
And although it's clear she has a bright future ahead of her on the talk show circuit, she's coy about whether she'll run for president.
On ""Oprah"" she said she wasn't retreating, just reloading.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""OPRAH"")
Does that mean you're reloading for 2012?
I'm concentrating on 2010 and making sure that we have issues tackled as Americans to make sure that we're on the right road.
(Unintelligible) if you were thinking about it.
No, I wouldn't.
Not on this show.
No.
In the meantime, says conservative blogger Ed Morrissey, Palin is a hero to the tea party base of the GOP.

She will play a tremendous role as an activist in the conservative movement in getting people out and in drawing people who see her as someone very much like themselves, not somebody from the elite, not somebody from academia, but somebody who's, you know, a suburban mom, coming out of that same mold.
And if she does decide to run again, says former McCain strategist John Weaver...
She has some luxury that a lot of candidates who are thinking about running, you know, don't have.
Like she has 100 percent name ID.
But that name recognition is a mixed bag, because so much of the public views her negatively.
According to an ABC/Washington Post poll, 60 percent of Americans think Palin is not qualified to be president.
More than 50 percent say they would never vote for her.
Of course, inside the Republican primary electorate and particularly in caucus states like Iowa her support is much stronger.
But despite the enthusiasm for Palin at the grassroots of the Republican Party, it's very hard to find any Republican strategist who believes she will run again.
Here's former Republican Congressman Vin Weber.
